did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia records related to Richard Lamborn estate

bioghist.p: Robert Henry Lamborn (1835-1895) was a civil engineer, railroad magnate, realtor, and financier. He was also an amateur naturalist. His interest in the Academy dated from his childhood association with his uncle Jacob Peirce, who was once its librarian. He was a well-known beekeeper and later a member of the Academy. Lamborn willed his entire estate of more than a million dollars to the Academy to be used for biological and anthropological purposes. The inheritance being questioned by other heirs at law, a long legal battle ensued and eventually the bequest was evenly divided between the Academy and the relatives. The assets consisted, in part, of real property in various sections of the country, namely Colorado, Montana, Minnesota, Michigan, Wisconsin, and Pennsylvania. The lands were held for some years, gradually being sold and the income used for research.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers related to the estate of Robert Henry Lamborn. Papers include: correspondence between representatives of the Academy and realty companies, lawyers, and others (1885-1929); invoices and receipts for rent, maintenance on properties, and legal work; financial statements of the estate, tax statements, and bank statements; indentures, land grants, leases, and copies of wills; and blueprints, plans, and maps. This collection includes some correspondence of George Vaux, Treasurer of the Academy from 1894 to 1927.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
